biogHist.abstract: A lying-in home was a private home or hospital where mothers could give birth with the help of a midwife. From 1907, lying-in homes in Western Australia had to be registered (including those run by the government). In early years, the midwife may not have had formal qualifications but this changed in 1912. Midwives sometimes helped mothers who had to go out to work to find 'care' for their babies. Sometimes this involved adoption.
biogHist.p:
The State Children Act 1907 defined a lying-in home as:
' a place for the accommodation of females during their confinement and lying-in, and includes any home maintained for such purpose by the Government. (Section 4)' This Act had carried over some of the infant life protection elements in section 7 of the Health Act 1898 which had failed so dismally to protect infants and their families from the practice of baby farming. Licensing the premises where infants were born was a natural step forward in regulating the care of children and young people in the State. In 1918, registration for lying-in Homes became the responsibility of the Commissioner of Health, through the Health Act Amendment Act 1918.

The Health Act 1911 made it compulsory for all midwives to be registered and set up a Midwives Registration Board to ensure formal qualifications were developed for future midwives. These requirements came into effect on 1 January 1912. The number of lying-in homes fell as the requirements of midwifery training became more rigorous.

descriptiveNote.p: The Female Home was used as a lying-in home for destitute and single women.
The licensing provisions for maternity homes were brought under the Health Act with amendments in 1918.

archref.abstract: This is a digitised copy of a photographic print and is part of the Victoria Hobbs collection of photographs held by the State Library of Western Australia. The image shows staff and patients at Nurse Mulder's Maternity Home at 84 Varden Street, in the suburb of Piccadilly in Kalgoorlie. This was a reasonably large 'lying-in' or maternity home and was typical of others operating at the time in Western Australia.
